a b s t r a c t
Nanomaterials, like carbon nanotubes, graphene, metal and metal oxide nanoparticles, are increasingly applied in a wide range of areas with numerous benefits to economy and society. Large-scale production and applications of nanomaterials can increase the possibility of exposure to living organisms, pose risks to human health and ecosystems, and potentially lead to biodiversity losses. Previous environmental impact and safety studies that targeted nanomaterials typically focused on their toxicity, fate and

behavior; little attention was paid on biodiversity consequences. Evidence for acute biodiversity change derived from nanomaterials is very limited. Several organizations and researchers have started to discern the relationship between biodiversity and nanotechnology. Nevertheless, more efforts are desired to explore the impacts of nanomaterials on biodiversity.

eproductive and developmental toxicity of nanomaterials
Global biodiversity has continually declined in the past decade 2000–2010) [1]. A prerequisite in impeding biodiversity losses is o collect as many decline reasons as possible [1,2]. New emerging anomaterials such as carbon nanomaterials and metal nanopartiles could be considered as one of these reasons, as reproductive nd developmental toxicity of nanomaterials has been observed 3], possibly becoming a new threat to biodiversity. Among numerus nanomaterials [3,4], single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) an cause embryo death, angiogenesis inhibition and growth retaration in chicken [5]; multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) re able to lead to the death of zebrafish embryos and developental arrest [3]; C60 can induce the abnormalities and death of ice embryos [6]. Carbon nanomaterials were reported to pose a hreat to the reproduction and growth of invertebrates, such as aphnia magna [7] and earthworms [8]. Dissemination of nanoaterials in soil and water may be detrimental to the growth of lants where they can accumulate and produce phytotoxicity. The rowth inhibitions of red spinach by MWCNTs [9], and graphenenduced decrease in shoot and root lengths of tomato, red spinach nd cabbage [10] have been revealed. In addition to carbon nano-
aterials, the adverse impact of metal-based nanomaterials on the iving organisms after environmental exposure also received signifcant attention. Metal nanoparticles such as nano-Ag and nano-TiO2

The chronic toxicity of gold nanoparticles with different surface functionalities (21-day exposure) to Daphnia magna was investigated, indicating that it experienced decreased reproduction or reduced body size [13]. Biodiversity change may occur if normal reproduction and development of species are prevented.
Compositional shifts in microbial communities caused by nanomaterials
Evidence from microbial community studies also supports that nanomaterials would result in biodiversity changes. Soil microbial community composition significantly shifted with the treatments using metal-based engineered nanomaterials, where the biomass of Gram-positive bacteria, Gram-negative bacteria and fungi significantly decreased as compared to the control without these nanomaterials [14]. The bacterial community structure or composition was changed by Ag nanoparticles in biosolids [15]. The incorporation of TiO2 nanoparticles in soil decreased the diversity in bacterial community [16]. Rodrigues et al. [17] reported that soil fungal community could not recover after soil was exposed to SWCNTs, and soil bacterial community was transiently influenced. The authors further reported that fungi and bacteria related to nutrient cycling in soil were adversely affected by SWCNTs. Another study done by Priester et al. [18] showed that nanomaterials inhibited the growth of nitrogen-fixing bacteria. Taking the previous findings together, the native nutrient cycling and ecosystem functions may be altered in the presence of nanomaterials. After an extensive liter-

ehaviors and acute-chronic toxicity of nanomaterials
The adverse effects of nanomaterials on the biodiversity and nvironment can be affected by multiple factors, such as sensitivity nd exposure time (short- and long-term). Nanomaterials refer to he materials at approximately 1–100 nm nanoscale, which have
large modification of physico-chemical properties and exhibit ifferent behaviors as compared to bulk chemicals or materials 11]. The small size makes them capable of more easily entering he cells in contact with proteins and other molecules than bulk hemicals and materials [20,21]. Nanomaterials may induce more erious adverse effects on living organisms. For example, nano-Ag, ano-ZnO and nano-TiO2 at high concentrations have shown to ave more toxic effects on the survival, reproduction and growth of arthworms than bulk metal forms in soils amended with sewage ludges [22]. Both acute and chronic exposure experiments of nanoaterials over short and long periods of time were carried out, howing that the effects of nanomaterials on tested organisms are ften different between acute and chronic treatments [23–27]. For xample, in a study related to MWCNT exposure in Daphnia magna, he sensitivity of chronic lethality hazard testing is more than 5 imes that of the acute toxicity of MWCNTs [25]. Also, Panacek t al. [23] demonstrated that Ag nanoparticles presented the acute oxicity to Drosophila melanogaster at high concentrations above 0 mg L−1 and chronic toxicity at a low concentration of 5 mg L−1. he observed differences between these two treatments are due o highly dynamic features of ecosystems, environment, and the nteractions between nanomaterials and the tested organisms.
he road ahead
Overall, despite limited information on biodiversity conseuence of nanomaterials, the available data point to the fact that ide applications of nanomaterials would lead to biodiversity hange. Thus, there is an urgent need to assess biodiversity change aused by various nanomaterials under environmentally realistic onditions, especially those used widely, e.g. carbon nanomaterils, and Ag, ZnO and TiO2 nanoparticles. Biodiversity like climate, ir and water is global. Nanomaterial applications are also global. hese two “globalities” require us to make more cooperated and oordinated efforts all over the world. Before taking actions to proect biodiversity from nanomaterials, the consensus methods and tandards for measuring the impact of nanomaterials on biodiverity need to be made [28]. It is crucial to develop related regulations nd policies to prevent the biodiversity losses derived from nanoaterials, as the current environmental regulations often do not ake into account the nanomaterials [28,29]. Moreover, establishent of reliable models is fundamental to predict the interactions etween nanomaterials and the living organisms and their effects n biodiversity [30].

Dr. Xiaosheng Qin is currently an Associate Professor with School of Civil and Environmental Engineering in Nanyang Technological University, Singapore. He obtained his PhD degree from University of Regina, Canada in 2008. He serves (or served) as the Associate Editors or board members for several international journals. His research interests cover the topics of urban environmental modelling, water resources systems planning and management, and climate change impact assessment.

Dr. Guangming Zeng has been the head of the School of Environmental Science and Engineering at Hunan University since 1996. He received his PhD degree from Wuhan University in 1988. He was invited as reviewers for over 50 journals and has over 320 scientific publications (journal & conference papers) with total citations at 23870 and Hindex at 72. He is also the Most Cited Chinese Researchers in 2014–2016 according to Elsevier’s statistics. His current research interests include toxicity, environmental applications and potential risks of nanomaterials.
